newsitem.title: ZAIRE: Chronology of recent events in former Zaire.
newsitem.headline: Chronology of recent events in former Zaire.

text.p: Laurent Kabila's decision not to appoint a prime minister in the Democratic Republic of Congo on Friday is the latest major development in the country. Kabila's forces took the capital on May 17, ending seven months of civil war in the former Zaire.
Here is a chronology of major events:

Oct 7: Deputy governor of Zaire's South Kivu province tells 300,000-strong Banyamulenge community -- ethnic Tutsis settled in the region for generations -- to leave Zaire within a week or "be hunted down as rebels". Warning sparks a revolt.
Oct 24: Rebels seize their first major town, Uvira at the northern end of Lake Tanganyika. Six days later they seize Bukavu, capital of South Kivu province.
Nov 1: Rebels and Rwandan soldiers capture Goma, main town in east; about 500 people killed in battles.
Nov 14: Rebels bombard Mugunga, Zaire's biggest refugee camp, with rockets, mortars and heavy artillery for six hours.

Nov 15: Exodus of frightened Rwandan Hutu refugees from Mugunga and other camps. Up to 700,000 refugees return to Rwanda, the remainder flee west with armed Hutu hardliners blamed for 1994 genocide of minority Tutsis there.
Nov 24: Zaire marks 31 years of Mobutu's rule; Mobutu is in Europe where he had been since cancer surgery in Switzerland in August.
Dec 17: Mobutu flies home to a rousing reception; appoints new armed forces chief and reshuffles government to launch counter-offensive. He returns to France three weeks later.
Jan 20: Government launches counter-offensive; rebels led by Laurent Kabila advance on several fronts, including mineral-rich Shaba region.
March 3: Zaire's main human rights group speaks of persistent reports of rebels massacring Hutus in east.
March 15: Rebels capture Zaire's third city Kisangani.
March 22: Mobutu returns home after fresh cancer treatment.
March 27: Togo OAU summit on Zaire urges talks, a truce and backing for U.N. peace plan and OAU-U.N. special envoy Mohamed Sahnoun.
April 2 : Mobutu names arch rival Etienne Tshisekedi prime minister in place of Kengo wa Dondo; Tshisekedi names government from own loyalists, offers rebels posts. Offer rejected.
April 5: Rebels capture diamond mining centre of Mbuji-Mayi.
April 8 : Mobutu declares nationwide state of emergency.
April 9 : Rebels capture Zaire's second city of Lubumbashi, capital of mineral-rich Shaba province; Mobutu shunts aside Tshisekedi, names General Likulia Bolongo prime minister.
April 14: Tshisekedi supporters close down capital Kinshasa for two days as part of campaign to oust Mobutu.
April 25: U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan calls plight of Rwandan Hutu refugees in rebel-held areas "slow extermination".
April 27: Kabila gives United Nations 60 days to repatriate the Hutus.
April 30: Relief agencies begin airlift to Rwanda.
May 4: Ship-borne talks between Kabila and Mobutu hosted by South Africa's Nelson Mandela end inconclusively; ninety-one refugees crushed to death on train from Biaro, 41 km south of Kisangani.
May 13: Night-time curfew declared in Kinshasa.
May 14: Second ship-borne meeting between Kabila and Mobutu cancelled when rebel leader failed to attend.
May 15: Mandela, after meeting Kabila in Cape Town, says Mobutu wants four days' grace to study South African proposals for an orderly handover of power to the rebels.

May 16: A government spokesman says Mobutu "has ceased all intervention in the affairs of the state". Mobutu leaves Kinshasa for his northern jungle palace at Gbadolite, prompting speculation he is headed into exile. Army chief General Mahele Lieko Bokungo killed by presidential guard.

May 17: As his troops enter capital Kinshasa, Kabila says in a statement read at a news conference in Lubumbashi that he is taking over as head of state with agreement of generals in Kinshasa. He renames the country the Democratic Republic of Congo.
May 20: Kabila flies into Kinshasa after dark.
May 23: Kabila announces partial government but does not name a prime minister.
